titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Allyn Joslyn Papers PASC.0293
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Amanda Neal and Julie Graham; machine-readable finding aid created by Julie Graham.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-09-02 16:28:16 -0700.

did.abstract: Versatile character actor Allyn Joslyn's acting career spanned from the 1920's to the 1970's. The collection documents Joslyn's professional accomplishments as an actor and entertainer, and includes scripts for motion pictures, television, radio, and stage; press clippings focused on Joslyn's career; photographs (mainly stills) from various film, television, and stage productions; and a small amount of correspondence and ephemera.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Audio materials in this collection are restricted and require advance notice for use.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED AUDIO MATERIALS: Materials are not currently available for access and will require further processing and assessment. If you have questions about this material please email spec-coll@library.ucla.edu.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Allyn Joslyn Papers (Collection PASC 293). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Amanda Neal and Julie Graham.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

odd.head: UCLA Catalog Record ID
odd.p: UCLA Catalog Record ID: 9956029443606533

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Allyn Morgan Joslyn was born in Milford, PA. There is conflicting information about the date of his birth; it has been reported as July 21, 1901 and July 21, 1905. As a teenager, he began his career on the live stage and acted in many plays throughout the 1920s and '30s. In 1935, he starred on Broadway in George Abbott's production of Boy Meets Girl. His role as Robert Law brought accolades and led him to Hollywood.

Joslyn made his motion picture debut in They Won't Forget (1937). (The film also marked the first film appearance of Lana Turner.) Over the next several decades, Joslyn acted in numerous motion pictures for all of the major studios, often in comedic roles. Notable motion pictures in which Joslyn appeared include Only Angels Have Wings (1939), My Sister Eileen (1942), Heaven Can Wait (1943), and Titanic (1953), among others. Joslyn played the role of Mortimer Brewster in the original Broadway production of Arsenic and Old Lace (1941); however, the role was played by Cary Grant in the film version (1944). While working in both theater and motion pictures, he was actively writing and acting in radio shows.

Joslyn's television career included lead roles in the series, The Eve Arden Show, where he had an ongoing role as George Howell (1957-58), and McKeever and the Colonel where Joslyn starred as Colonel Harvey Blackwell (1962-63). He was a regular on The Ray Bolger Show (1953-54) and also made many guest appearances in a variety of television productions throughout the 1950s and '60s. These include The Addams Family, Rawhide, The Untouchables, and several programs for Ford Theatre. Joslyn made his final film appearance in The Brothers O'Toole (1973). He died of cardiac failure on January 21, 1981 at the Motion Picture and Television Country House in Woodland Hills, CA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of scripts, press clippings, photographs, correspondence, and memorabilia documenting the career of actor and entertainer Allyn Joslyn. The bulk of the collection is comprised of scripts for motion picture, television, radio and stage projects featuring/including Joslyn and/or items which may have been submitted to Joslyn for his consideration. Included are scripts for My Sister Eileen (1942), Heaven Can Wait (1943), The Eve Arden Show (1957-58), and McKeever and the Colonel (1962-63), among others. There is also a small collection of stills from selected motion picture, stage and television productions, including Boy Meets Girl, No Time for Comedy, and McKeever and the Colonel, among others.

The press clippings include a mixture of reviews, publicity, and promotional write-ups about Joslyn and/or the various projects or events in which he was involved during his career. There is also a small amount of correspondence that includes letters, telegrams, and/or cards related to both personal matters and professional activities. The memorabilia is from events or performances that Joslyn was either involved with or attended. Additionally, there is a small number of entertainment-related magazine publications that do not appear related to Joslyn's personal or professional life.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Motion Picture Projects
Radio Projects
Stage Productions
Television Projects
Correspondence
Memorabilia
Publicity Stills and Photographs
Press Reviews and Publicity
Publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Motion Picture series contains script material and a small collection of stills related to motion picture projects featuring or including Joslyn. Included are scripts for My Sister Eileen, This Thing Called Love, Titanic, and Heaven Can Wait, among others. Additionally, there are scripts which may have been submitted to Joslyn for his consideration. The stills document selected film projects in which Joslyn was involved such as Café Society, Deep South, Hollywood Hotel, and No Time for Comedy, among others. The series is arranged alphabetically by motion picture project title. See also the Press Clipping series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Radio series contains script material and a small number of audio recordings for radio projects in which Joslyn was involved. The series is arranged alphabetically into sub-series by radio series title. The processor created the sub-series Unknown Radio Projects for items not identified with a produced radio program and which may have been project ideas submitted to Joslyn for his consideration. The files within each sub-series are arranged alphabetically by episode or program title. Among the scripts are writings for The Joan Davis Show and advertising spots for Velure Lotion. The sound recordings include My Life of Caroline, Skylark, and Talk of the Town presented by the Lady Esther Screen Guild Players. (The "Screen Guild was a charity show donating all star fees" to the Motion Picture Relief Fund which was used to build the Motion Picture Country House for "aging and indigent screen stars." Joslyn would later live his last days at the Motion Picture Country House). Use of audio material requires production of listening copies. See also Press Clippings series for press clippings.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: RESTRICTED ACCESS - Use of audio material requires production of listening copies. Prepared for Joslyn by Foote, Cone, and Belding. Includes additional Hollywood Star Time recording dated 7/28/44. (4 discs). Personalized record album in box 22.

scopecontent.p: The Stage Projects consists of scripts for stage productions featuring Joslyn and/or submitted to him for his consideration. The series is arranged alphabetically by production title. Several of the scripts are undated; dated materials range from 1937-1952. See also the Press Clippings series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Television Projects series consists mostly of scripts and a small number of stills and press clippings for television projects where Joslyn was either a featured player or had a guest role. The series is arranged alphabetically into subseries by television series or television program title. The processor created the sub-series Other Television Projects for the small number of items not identified with a produced television program and which may have been project ideas submitted to Joslyn for his consideration. The files within each sub-series are arranged alphabetically by episode or project title. Among the many television projects are 25-plus scripts and a small number of stills from the 1960s television series McKeever and the Colonel, where Joslyn starred as Colonel Harvey Blackwell from 1962-1963. Additionally, there is a small number of scripts, stills, and press clippings for The Eve Arden Show, where Joslyn had an ongoing role as George Howell (1957-58). See also the Press Clipping series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series is a mix of letters, telegrams, and/or cards to Joslyn that appear to be related to both personal matters and professional activities. Also included are a very small number of items to Josylyn's wife and daughter. The files are arranged alphabetically by file titles which reflect the contents of the folders. All file titles have been supplied by the processor.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Including Charles Coburn and Glenn Ford among others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Memorabilia series includes a small collection of playbills, programs, memorabilia, and other printed ephemera collected by Joslyn. Also included is a small amount of membership mailings/printed ephemera from professional organizations. The files are arranged alphabetically by folder title which reflect the contents of the folder. All file titles have been supplied by the processor.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: With address book, miscellaneous handwritten notes, SAG identification card, MGM questionnaire pertaining to the Draft, menu card from the S.S. Saramacca. Also includes Actors Equity card for AJ's wife Dorothy Yockel.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Lists editor Alan Allyn (could this be AJ?).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Press Clippings series is a mixture of reviews, publicity, and promotional write-ups about Joslyn and/or the various projects or events in which he was involved during his career. The series is arranged chronologically into sub-series by decade. The chronological arrangement of the series often brings together information about particular projects, during specific periods of Joslyn's career such as Arsenic and Old Lace (stage version), Immortal Sergeant, Titanic, and The Wife Takes a Flyer. Whenever possible, known project titles are listed in the notes field. A portion of the clippings were sent to Joslyn by the Henry Arnsten Public Relations company. The files within each sub-series are arranged chronologically. Joslyn's name appears in the notes field in the abbreviated form, "AJ."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Publication series consists of industry publications that appear to have been collected by Joslyn and do not appear to be directly related to his personal or professional life. The bulk of the series are issues of the Motion Picture Daily (1945), of which Joslyn was a subscriber. Other titles include the Hollywood Reporter, Variety, and single issues of miscellaneous magazines. The series is arranged alphabetically by publication titles.

odd.head: General note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Publicity Stills and Photographs series includes a small number of stills and photographs that were not identified with any specific motion picture, television, stage, or radio related project. Included are a small number of head shots of Joslyn, four USO-related photographs, and a very small number of personal photographs with family members. The files are arranged alphabetically by file titles reflecting the contents of each folder.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Duplicates of photographs in the collection consisting mostly of McKeever and the Colonel and AJ head shots.

did.unittitle: Allyn Joslyn and others photographs - 11 oversize items

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Headshots of Joslyn (3), scene shots from unknown stage production (4 including one duplicate), and unknown female(s) (4 including two duplicates).

did.unittitle: Allyn Joslyn head shots and publicity stills - 37 items

odd.p: Includes a photograph of a sketch of young AJ.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Publicity shots alone and with others, mostly unidentified (30 items).
